Scientists are astonished after the discovery of a solar system located 30 light-years from Earth, which undermines our current understanding of the processes of planets formation, as in this arrangement a large planet similar to Jupiter is circling a small star called red dwarf.
An artistic illustration of the planet's gas-type giant GJ 3512b circulating around the central star being a red dwarp, published on 26 September 2019.
In general, stars are much larger than even the largest planets circling around them.
However, as scientists said on Thursday, in this case the star and planet slightly differ in size.

The size of a star named GJ 3512 is about 12% of the size of the Sun, while the mass of the planet that revolves around it is at least half the mass of Jupiter, the largest planet of our solar system.

"Yes, it's an absolute surprise," "said astrophysicist Juan Carlos Morales of the Catalan Institute of Space Research at the Spanish Institute of Space Research, which has been at the forefront of research published in the journal Science."

The discovery is surprising, as the theoretical models of the formation of solar systems suggest that low-mass stars usually become parent stars for smaller planets similar to Earth or smaller Neptunes.
"In this case, we discovered a gas-type planet giant similar to Jupiter circling a very small star," "added Morales."
The planet, which, like Jupiter, consists mainly of gas, was discovered using a telescope at the Calar Alto Observatory in Spain.
It encircled its star after a very elliptical orbit, and the full lap lasts 204 days.
The red dwarfs are small and have a relatively low surface temperature.
The star GJ 3512 is not only much smaller than the Sun, but to some extent it has a size comparable to the size of a very large planet, as it is only about approx. 35% higher than Jupiter.
They emit less energy, so they are pale than the sun, and their surface temperature is rather low and it is roughly below 3800 (degrees) Kelvin (6380 degrees Fahrenheit / 3527 degrees Celsius).
"That's why they have a reddish color," "said Morales."

"There is evidence of the existence of the second planet currently circulating around this star, while the third planet may have been expelled from the star system in the past, which may explain the elliptical orbit of a planet similar to Jupiter," " stated Morales. "
The planets are formed from the same interstellar drive of gas and dust that gives birth to the star around which planets are circulating.

According to the leading model of the formation of planets called the model of acretion, initially the object is formed from particles in the disk, and the force of gravity of the planet in the early stage of development allows the formation of the atmosphere from the surrounding gas.
This unusual arrangement can explain a competitive model called the gravitational instability model.
"In such a case, a protoplanetary disc around a young star can be a bit more massive than we expect and it can be cold," "said Morales."
This leads to a disk stability disorder, and therefore some dense areas may occur.
These masses may rise up to the point of collapse and the creation of a planet.
